content.result:
L230: many laptops are assembled in China. And right now, the current tax on Chinese 
L231: imports 【104†could go as high as 125 percent†go.skimresources.com】.
L232: 
L233: Unfortunately, some retailers and manufacturers are taking advantage of the 
L234: situation with subtle tricks to get you buying less-than-worthwhile models. 
L235: Here’s what you need to avoid and what you should do instead if you need to buy 
L236: a laptop before tariff price bumps kick in.
L237: 
L238: ## Trick #1: Suspiciously good sale prices 
L239: 
L240: The best-selling laptop on Amazon right now is an unspecified Lenovo IdeaPad 
L241: that’s being sold by a third-party seller named AZXUT STORE—and this product 
L242: listing is highly suspicious.
L243: 
L244: 【105†It first appeared on Amazon in early April†go.skimresources.com】 at a price
L245:  of $1,499, then was cut down to $399. It has since increased to $429, meaning 
L246: the laptop is listed as “71% off.” It’s also labeled as the “#1 Best Seller” in 
L247: the Traditional Laptop Computers category. It even lists 32GB of memory and a 
L248: 1TB solid state drive. With all that, I can’t blame anyone who bought this over 
L249: the past few days. It looks like a killer deal. But it isn’t.
L250: 
L251: [Image 1: Lenovo IdeaPad laptop suspicious sale pricing on Amazon product 
L252: listing]
L253: 
L254: Matt Smith / Foundry 
L255: 
L256: The first sign that something’s fishy is the processor. The listing claims that 
L257: this laptop has an Intel Celeron N4500, a dual-core processor that released in 
L258: 2021. The Celeron N4500 was among the slowest processors produced by Intel at 
L259: the time, and today its performance is truly abysmal. According to Geekbench 6, 
L260: a typical laptop with a Celeron N4500 【106†hits a multi-core score of 
L261: 731†go.skimresources.com】. Meanwhile, Intel’s Core Ultra 120U—a modern chip 
L262: found in many budget laptops—【107†typically scores about 
L263: 7,500†go.skimresources.com】.
L264: 
L265: To me, this stinks of a scam that’s preying on less knowledgeable folk. The 
L266: seller, AZXUT STORE, has many recent 1-star reviews. Some customers say the 
L267: products they received were used, that they didn’t match their respective 
L268: listings, or that they received nothing at all.
L269: 
L270: I couldn’t find contact information for AZXUT STORE, and the contact button on 
L271: Amazon’s website directed me to a chatbot. I’ve reached out to Amazon for 
L272: comment on the situation.
L273: 
L274: ## Trick #2: Deceptive marketing claims 
L275: 
L276: The #1 best-selling laptop on Amazon is plenty suspicious, but it isn’t the only
L277:  way sellers are looking to pull one over on shoppers. Some are trying to trick 
L278: buyers by misrepresenting what a laptop can do.
L279: 
L280: Gaming laptops are a particularly deep reservoir of terrible listings. A search 
L281: for “gaming laptop” on Amazon will surface comically terrible laptops like the 
L282: 【108†ACEMAGIC AX16PRO†www.amazon.com】, 【109†NIMO N155†www.amazon.com】, and the… 
L283: uh… “【110†Gaming Laptop, Laptop Computer, Computer Laptop†www.amazon.com】.”
L284: 
L285: [Image 2: Deceptive gaming laptop product listings on Amazon search results]
L286: 
L287: Matt Smith / Foundry 
L288: 
L289: The ACEMAGIC, being sold by a company called SMART DEALS WAREHOUSE, is guilty of
L290:  the first trick mentioned above with a very high listed price of $1,600 that’s 
L291: discounted down to $500. But it pours salt on the wound with a second trick: it 
L292: misrepresents itself as a gaming laptop. The listing claims it’s an “ACEMAGIC 
L293: 2025 Gaming Laptop” and uses generic marketing images with attractive anime 
L294: characters and race cars, with particular focus on the laptop’s AMD Radeon Vega 
L295: 8 graphics.
L296: 
L297: As you probably already know, the Vega 8 is the integrated graphics solution 
L298: included with many AMD Ryzen chips. Not only is it an iGPU, it’s not even the 
L299: latest iGPU. The Ryzen 5700U on this laptop was launched back in 2021, so its 
L300: equipped Radeon integrated graphics are a couple generations behind the latest 
L301: hardware.
L302: 
L303: 【111†PC World’s review of the HP Envy x360】, a laptop with the same Ryzen 5700U 
L304: and Radeon Vega 8 graphics, found it achieved a 3Dmark Time Spy score of roughly
L305:  1,500. Laptops with the latest integrated graphics from Intel and AMD tend to 
L306: score at least 3,000 in that test.
L307: 
L308: Can the ACEMAGIC laptop load and play a PC game? Sure. But the experience isn’t 
L309: going to be any better than what you can get with any other budget or mid-range 
L310: laptop with integrated graphics.
L311: 
L312: ## Trick #3: High-pressure sales tactics 
L313: 
L314: Vaio, the remnant of the Sony Vaio brand (which Sony sold years ago), was quick 
L315: to take advantage of the April tariff announcement. The company swiftly sent out
L316:  a marketing email 【112†that urged shoppers to buy a laptop now at “tariff-free”
L317:  prices】 before the tariffs went into effect.
L318: 
L319: This trick is a bit less shady than the first two. The laptops that Vaio linked 
L320: to in the email were no different than the laptops they usually offer, nor did 
L321: they have marked-up prices or ancient hardware. Still, the email was an obvious 
L322: scare tactic meant to push consumers into making panic buys, which could lead 
L323: shoppers into buyer’s remorse.
L324: 
L325: [Image 3: Example Vaio FS 16 laptop being sold on Costco listing]
L326: 
L327: Matt Smith / Foundry 
L328: 
L329: Vaio laptops don’t have a strong presence in the United States. While there’s 
L330: nothing wrong with the configurations they offer, Vaio laptops are pretty 
L331: unremarkable. And I’d say they’re on the pricey side, too. A laptop like the 
L332: Vaio FS—【113†sold for $1,099.99 online via Costco†go.skimresources.com】—is a 
L333: decent laptop, but if you had the chance to look into similar machines, you’d 
L334: likely find a better deal… like, say, the 【114†Asus Vivobook S 16 Flip for 
L335: $1,069†click.linksynergy.com】.
L336: 
L337: Vaio is hardly alone. I’ve received several marketing emails from other 
L338: companies in the past few days that play up these fears. Plus, Vaio laptops are 
L339: advertised as “proudly manufactured in Japan,” which is funny since it means 
L340: Vaio laptops won’t be subject to the steepest tariffs. In that sense, US tariffs
L341:  on China could work out well for Vaio in the long run. But that also means 
L342: there isn’t as much pressure to buy a Vaio ASAP.
L343: 
L344: ## If you need to buy a laptop now, do this 
L345: 
L346: You now know three common tricks that retailers and manufacturers are trying to 
L347: pull to get you buying a laptop now. But knowing these tricks only tells you 
L348: what you need to avoid. What should you actually look for? It’s obviously a 
L349: complex topic, but I have some simple advice.
L350: 
L351: First, identify what CPU (and GPU, if applicable) the laptop has. If you can’t 
L352: find that information in the listing, don’t buy it.
L353: 
L354: Then, once you know the CPU (and/or GPU), pull up your favorite search engine 
L355: and search for that exact CPU (and/or GPU) to find the date it was released. 
L356: You’ll want a CPU that launched in the last year or two, and a GPU that launched
L357:  in the last three years. If the CPU and/or GPU in the laptop you’re eyeing is 
L358: older than those thresholds, yet the retailer is claiming that the laptop is

L344: ## If you need to buy a laptop now, do this 
L345: 
L346: You now know three common tricks that retailers and manufacturers are trying to 
L347: pull to get you buying a laptop now. But knowing these tricks only tells you 
L348: what you need to avoid. What should you actually look for? It’s obviously a 
L349: complex topic, but I have some simple advice.
L350: 
L351: First, identify what CPU (and GPU, if applicable) the laptop has. If you can’t 
L352: find that information in the listing, don’t buy it.
L353: 
L354: Then, once you know the CPU (and/or GPU), pull up your favorite search engine 
L355: and search for that exact CPU (and/or GPU) to find the date it was released. 
L356: You’ll want a CPU that launched in the last year or two, and a GPU that launched
L357:  in the last three years. If the CPU and/or GPU in the laptop you’re eyeing is 
L358: older than those thresholds, yet the retailer is claiming that the laptop is 
L359: “new,” then don’t buy it.
L360: 
L361: For more guidance on how to buy a good budget laptop without being cheated or 
L362: swindled, see our articles on 【115†minimum specs for a budget laptop】 and 
L363: 【116†what a $500 laptop looks like these days】. For straight-up recommendations,
L364:  check out the 【117†best laptops under $500】.
L365: 
L366: ## 3 great laptops you can buy right now 
L367: 
L368: We have a frequently updated 【88†guide to the best laptops】, which is always a 
L369: great place to start when you need a new machine. But if you’re buying quickly 
L370: before tariffs fully kick in, here are three high-quality Chinese-made laptops 
L371: to jump on before prices shoot up.
L372: 
L373: [Image 4: Asus Zenbook 14 OLED]
L374: 
L375: Asus

L73: Chinese laptop brands have grown from low-cost alternatives to global tech

L87: ## Overview of the laptop market in China
L88: 
L89: In 2024, the global PC market began to recover after the slowdown that followed 
L90: the pandemic boom. According to the latest 【27†Canalys†www.canalys.com】 data, 
L91: total shipments of desktops, notebooks, and workstations grew for the fifth 
L92: consecutive quarter, rising by 5.0% to reach 67.9 million units by the end of 
L93: the year.
L94: 
L95: 【28†Mainland China’s PC market†www.canalys.com】 also returned to growth. In Q4 
L96: 2024, shipments increased by 2% year on year, driven mainly by an 8% rise in 
L97: consumer demand. Notebooks led the rebound with a 6% growth, reaching 8.6 
L98: million units, while desktop shipments declined 9% to 2.9 million units.
L99: 
L100: Looking ahead, Canalys projects a 3% growth in China’s PC market in 2025, and 1%
L101:  growth in its tablet market. This would bring shipments to 41 million units and
L102:  31.9 million units, respectively, with both categories supported by government 
L103: subsidies and new product launches from major brands.
L104: 
L105: Revenue in China’s laptop market is expected to hit 【29†US$11.2 billion in 
L106: 2025†www.statista.com】. A major trend driving this growth is the rising demand 
L107: for ultra-thin, lightweight laptops, as more consumers prioritize portability 
L108: and convenience.
L109: 
L110: Another important factor: with 【30†Microsoft ending support for Windows 10 in 
L111: October 2025†www.microsoft.com】, millions of users worldwide are expected to 
L112: upgrade their devices, fueling even stronger sales momentum.
L113: 
L114: ## Top Chinese laptop brands
L115: 
L116: Looking for the best Chinese laptops? Here are the current top Chinese laptop 
L117: brands you need to be paying attention to.

L119: ### 1. Lenovo

L125:   * Key Markets: North America, Europe, Asia
L126: 
L127: Why Lenovo Stands Out   
L128: Lenovo has been the world’s #1 laptop brand by shipments for the last several 
L129: years, beating HP and Dell. In 2024 Q4, Lenovo shipped 【32†16.9 million units 
L130: worldwide†canalys.com】. Its ThinkPad series remains the gold standard for 
L131: business laptops, while Legion has gained popularity among gamers for its power 
L132: and value.
L133: 
L134: Lenovo also leads in innovation, with the ThinkPad X1 Fold (foldable laptop) and
L135:  Yoga 9i (2-in-1 convertible) pushing the envelope.

L140:   * Recognized brand in corporate, education, and gaming sectors
L141:   * Strong resale value and brand trust
L142: 
L143: ### 2. Huawei
L144: 
L145:   * Focus: Premium ultrabooks (MateBook series)
L146:   * Key Markets: China, Europe, Middle East
L147:   * Unique Selling Points: Sleek design, long battery life, HarmonyOS 
L148: integration
L149: 
L150: Why Huawei Stands Out   
L151: Huawei’s laptop computers are praised for their long battery life and impressive
L152:  displays. Their MateBook X Pro has earned praise for its thin, MacBook-like 
L153: design (3k display) and powerful performance. Huawei also pushes ecosystem 
L154: integration with seamless syncing between laptops, smartphones, and tablets (all
L155:  running HarmonyOS).
L156: 
L157: While Huawei laptops aren’t sold in the United States, they’re hot in Europe, 
L158: Asia, and the Middle East. Resellers in those regions can leverage the premium 
L159: feel and MacBook-like experience to attract high-end buyers.
L160: 
L161: Why It Works for Businesses
L162:

L164:   * Demand among professionals and students
L165:   * Brand loyalty among existing Huawei users (phones, tablets)

L167: ### 3. Xiaomi
L168:

L68: Shopping for a laptop can be daunting. Over a dozen major manufacturers release 
L69: new models every year. While some companies are more reputed for producing 
L70: higher-quality products, even the best laptop brands sometimes release models 
L71: with design flaws or too many compromises. Also, there are often complaints of 
L72: poor quality control, inadequate after-sale customer support, and other issues 
L73: associated with a particular manufacturer. As you may have guessed, there isn't 
L74: really a best laptop brand, as it depends entirely on your needs and 
L75: preferences, though quite a few, like Apple, ASUS, Dell, and Microsoft, stand 
L76: out.
L77: 
L78: We've bought and tested over 155 laptops, including models from over a dozen 
L79: brands, and below are our recommendations for the best brands for laptops. The 
L80: order in which these laptops appear in the article doesn't represent any 
L81: ranking; they're listed alphabetically. For more options, check out our 
L82: recommendations for the 【8†best laptops】, the 【12†best business laptops】, and 
L83: the 【7†best gaming laptops】. If you want to learn more about how we test laptops
L84:  or our review process, check out this 【55†article】, where we give you a quick 
L85: rundown of each step from the moment we purchase the laptop to the final 
L86: published review.

L152: get bright enough to combat glare in most indoor settings. The keyboard feels 
L153: spacious, albeit slightly mushy, and the touchpad is large and responsive. You 
L154: get Wi-Fi 6E wireless connectivity, a 1080p webcam, and a wide port selection 
L155: that includes two Thunderbolt 4s and an HDMI.

L229: ## Chuwi CoreBook X: 30-second review 
L230: 
L231: Chuwi is a Chinese manufacturer that entered the market in 2014, first with a 
L232: selection of Android tablets and then diversifying into laptops and mini PCs.
L233: 
L234: The CoreBook X is typical of inexpensive Chinese laptops that are surprisingly 
L235: well-engineered, using Intel, which is a few steps removed from cutting-edge 
L236: processor technology.
L237: 
L238: The model reviewed here uses a 12th-generation Intel Core i5 mobile processor 
L239: that first appeared in January 2022. It comes with 16GB of DDR4 memory, 512GB of
L240:  storage, and a 14-inch 1440p resolution display. Chuwi also claims it covers 
L241: 100% sRGB color gamut, which puts it on par with some of the 【42†best laptops 
L242: for photo editing】, but at a budget price.
L243: 
L244: It lacks an easy means to upgrade the storage or any USB ports better than USB 
L245: 3.2 Gen 1 (old USB 3.0). It also uses an older GPU technology, and it lacks any 
L246: biometric access control.
L247: 
L248: Therefore, that’s an old and somewhat tired specification out of the box, even 
L249: if the quality of the build is high and plenty of metal is used in its 
L250: construction.
L251: 
L252: The big selling point is that it costs less than $400, but the battery won’t 
L253: last a full working day and transferring files to external SSDs will be 
L254: relatively slow.
L255: 
L256: If you have a modest budget and requirements, then the CoreBook X might work for
L257:  you, but a low-cost AMD Ryzen laptop might deliver a better experience.
L258: 
L259:   * 【43†Chuwi CoreBook X (14-inch 512GB) at Walmart for $369.99†buy.geni.us】
L260: 
L261: ## Chuwi CoreBook X: Price and availability
L262: 
L263: [Image 20: Chuwi CoreBook X]
L264: 
L265: (Image credit: Mark Pickavance)
L266: 
L267:   * How much does it cost? From $370/£320/€358 
L268:   * When is it out? Available now 
L269:   * Where can you get it? Direct from 【44†Chuwi†store.chuwi.com】
L270: 
L271: Something is odd about the availability of the CoreBook X that makes me wonder 
L272: if it’s a limited run, possibly using a limited supply of the older Intel 
L273: processors that have been made available.
L274: 
L275: While most Chuwi models appear on all the regional Chuwi sites and on Amazon in 
L276: most regions, the CoreBook X is only available on the global outlet.
L277: 
L278: There are currently four CoreBook X SKUs, with one using the i3-1220P CPU, two 
L279: using the i5-12450H, and one using the i5-1235U.
L280: 
L281: The two i5-1245H models are a standard CoreBook X that’s the review hardware, 
L282: and Chuwi also makes a CoreBook XPro option with an even bigger 15.6-inch 
L283: display, and slightly more battery capacity.
L284: 
L285: The i3 model starts at $369, and the i5-12450 is $399 in the USA. They are 
L286: €357.20 and €386.24 in Europe and £297.51 or £321.69 in the UK.
L287: 
L288: For those interested, the CoreBook XPro is $429/€415.28/£345.88, and I couldn’t 
L289: find the i5-1235U model in the Chuwi store.
L290: 
L291: Typically, Intel Core i5 laptops start at around $500, like the Acer Aspire 5 15
L292:  Slim Laptop. But these can use DDR5 memory, have USB 3.2 Gen 2 ports, and 
L293: biometrics.
L294: 
L295: There is a reason the CoreBook X is so cheap, and this factor impacts the 
L296: usability of this equipment. Most other laptops using this platform are either 
L297: discontinued or end-of-line.
L298: 
L299:   * Value: 3 / 5

L370: ## Chuwi CoreBook X: Design
L371: 
L372: [Image 21: Chuwi CoreBook X]
L373: 
L374: (Image credit: Mark Pickavance)
L375: 
L376:   * Nice build quality 
L377:   * High-res screen 
L378:   * Upgradable 
L379:   * No biometrics 
L380: 
L381: Considering how cheap the CoreBook X is, the quality of construction is 
L382: impressive. But it’s mostly plastic on the inner surface and only metal on the 
L383: underside and outer lid, connected to a more rigid internal chassis.
L384: 
L385: A fourteen-inch 3:2 ratio IPS display with a 2160×1440 resolution can be useful 
L386: if you need to see large documents or spreadsheets. What’s slightly odd about 
L387: the chosen panel is that it’s not as saturated as some IPS displays I’ve seen, 
L388: and at the higher brightness settings, it can appear a little washed out. And, 
L389: because of the aspect, watching TV or file content results in large black bars 
L390: at the top and bottom of the presentation.
L391: 
L392: The keyboard uses the full width of the laptop, although it doesn’t manage to 
L393: find room for a numeric pad, and the touchpad is one of those unfortunate 
L394: flexible click varieties. I wasn’t expecting much from either, but the keyboard 
L395: works well enough.
L396: 
L397: If possible, I would like to see inside laptops to determine what upgrade 
L398: options are available.
L399: 
L400: That was a more complicated exercise than it initially looked, even if you can 
L401: get to the unused SODIMM memory slot merely by removing a plate held in place by
L402:  two screws.
L403: 
L404: [Image 22: Chuwi CoreBook X]
L405: 
L406: (Image credit: Mark Pickavance)
L407: 
L408: To remove the underside involves nine visible screws, one of which was 
L409: underneath a QA sticker. With these off, the underside still wouldn’t release 
L410: until I discovered a further two screws hidden under the rear rubber feet.

L209: Feature 
L210: 
L211: # Buying a budget laptop? Don’t go below these minimum specs
L212: 
L213: If you want an affordable laptop that won't drive you crazy, pay attention to 
L214: these crucial specs. 
L215: 
L216: [Image 0: Josh Hendrickson]
L217: 
L218: By 【102†Josh Hendrickson】
L219: 
L220: Contributor, PCWorld  Apr 16, 2025 3:30 am PDT
L221: 
L222: [Image 1: Laptop with black screen and three dollar bills laid out on keyboard] 
L223: 
L224: 【103†Image: Kris / Pixabay†pixabay.com】 
L225: 
L226: It’s easy to spend a lot of money on a laptop, but you don’t have to. In fact, 
L227: most people don’t need to spend much at all. Whether you’re on a budget or 
L228: you’re buying for a student or child, sometimes the best laptop is the one 
L229: that’s most affordable. 
L230: 
L231: But just because you’re spending less doesn’t mean you should settle for less. 
L232: To make sure your laptop won’t leave you frustrated and pulling your hair out, 
L233: there are a few key specs that you shouldn’t compromise on—or else you’ll 
L234: probably regret your purchase.
L235: 
L236: What counts as a budget laptop? In this case, we’re aiming for a price around 
L237: $500 and we’re using 【104†PCWorld’s best budget laptop picks】 to get a sense of 
L238: what’s possible, what’s reasonable, and what’s non-negotiable. Just be aware 
L239: that you’ll give up some luxuries (like a dedicated graphics card) at this price
L240:  point, but you’ll end up with a great daily driver laptop for work, school, and
L241:  everyday activities.
L242: 
L243: That said, let’s dive into the most important specs for a budget laptop and the 
L244: absolute minimum acceptable for each one.
L245: 
L246: > Further reading: 【105†Buying a laptop before China tariffs kick in? Don’t fall
L247:  for these tricks】
L248: 
L249: ## Operating system
L250: 
L251: [Image 2: best buy chromebook sale]
L252: 
L253: Asus, Samsung, Lenovo 
L254: 
L255: The very first choice you must make is the operating system. And if you’re on a 
L256: budget, you really only have two options: Windows or ChromeOS. (You could also 
L257: run Linux if you’re tech-savvy enough, but if you know enough to run Linux, you 
L258: likely don’t need this article.)
L259: 
L260: Windows is the de facto choice because it’s used everywhere, everyone is 
L261: familiar with it, and most apps “just work” on Windows computers. But it has a 
L262: lot of system overhead so it doesn’t run as well on low-end hardware and you 
L263: might experience subpar performance.
L264: 
L265: ChromeOS, which is the operating system for Chromebooks, is far more restricted 
L266: in what apps it can run. If it isn’t available in the Chrome Web Store, you’re 
L267: pretty much out of luck. (Sure, you can use workarounds like remote desktop-ing 
L268: into a separate Windows machine, but that kind of defeats the point of buying a 
L269: budget laptop!)
L270: 
L271: That said, there are 【106†plenty of good reasons to buy a Chromebook over a 
L272: laptop】, like the bang-for-your-buck on performance and price, so don’t be 
L273: turned off. Chromebooks are quite good these days.
L274: 
L275: Note: If you’re buying a laptop for a student, you should definitely check with 
L276: their school first because some schools have mandatory OS requirements. Even if 
L277: they don’t, they might have specific software needs—and if that software isn’t 
L278: available on ChromeOS, you’ll have to go with Windows.
L279: 
L280: What about MacBooks? While it’s possible to buy a MacBook on a budget, you’ll 
L281: have to give up a lot in the process—or stretch your definition of “budget.” 
L282: Even the cheapest MacBooks far exceed $500, and they tend to be older discounted
L283:  models. Generally speaking, Macs aren’t great for getting the best specs for 
L284: your money.
L285: 
L286: ## RAM
L287: 
L288: [Image 3: Framework Laptop taken apart with parts ordered neatly]
L289: 
L290: Framework 
L291: 
L292: You can think of RAM like the amount of workspace you have on your desk: more 
L293: RAM means more space to concurrently run apps and keep numerous files open, 
L294: allowing you to jump between and multitask without having to close and re-open 
L295: stuff all the time.
L296: 
L297: That’s why RAM is key to laptop performance, and it’s important to get a laptop 
L298: that has enough RAM to run smoothly. I recommend a minimum 8GB of RAM, but bump 
L299: it up to 16GB if you want to “future proof” against growing needs in the future.
L300: 
L301: The good news is, finding solid laptops with at least 8GB of RAM isn’t 
L302: difficult—but if your budget is limited to around $300, you’re likely to be 
L303: stuck with 4GB options at best. If you can afford it, it’s definitely worth the 
L304: extra cash to hit 8GB, even on Chromebooks. Otherwise, you’ll find that your 
L305: laptop’s sluggishness will affect your enjoyment of it.
L306: 
L307: ## CPU
L308: 
L309: [Image 4: Der CPU-Prozessor-Chip überhitzt und brennt im Sockel auf der 
L310: Hauptplatine des Computers]
L311: 
L312: BLKstudio / Shutterstock.com 
L313: 
L314: When it comes to CPUs on budget laptops, you have to temper your expectations. 
L315: You won’t be able to get anything truly powerful, but you will be able to find 
L316: something that suits your needs and gets you through non-intensive tasks like 
L317: office work, studying, and watching videos.
L318: 
L319: Among the more affordable Windows laptops, Intel i3 and i5 processors are the 
L320: most common options. Ideally you should opt for the i5, but you can settle for 
L321: an i3 if you’re on a tight budget; it should keep up with regular tasks as long 
L322: as you pair it with at least 8GB of RAM. AMD Ryzen 3 and Ryzen 5 processors are 
L323: also frequently seen in budget-tier laptops, and they can save you a little more
L324:  money than their Intel alternatives.
L325: 
L326: In Chromebooks, you’ll mostly find Intel i3 and i5 processors along with 
L327: MediaTek options. MediaTek processors are typically found in budget phones 
L328: because they have better battery life, but they have the disadvantage of being 
L329: less powerful.
L330: 
L331: Either way, opt for Intel or AMD if you care about performance. Just don’t 
L332: expect any high-end gaming! You’d need a dedicated GPU for that, and that’s not 
L333: happening in a budget laptop.
L334: 
L335: ## Battery life
L336: 
L337: [Image 5: laptop battery level indicator]
L338: 
L339: Panos Sakalakis / Unsplash 
L340: 
L341: You have lots of options when it comes to battery life, even in the affordable 
L342: laptop territory. Not only do weaker processors give you longer staying power, 
L343: but larger batteries can help too—if you’re willing to sacrifice weight and 
L344: portability.
L345: 
L346: And here, too, is an area where your choice of OS matters. Generally speaking, 
L347: Chromebooks usually last longer on a single charge than an equivalent Windows 
L348: laptop.
L349: 
L350: If you travel frequently or simply prefer to use your laptop unplugged, then aim
L351:  for one that promises 10 to 12 hours of battery life. Most manufacturers 
L352: overpromise and under deliver, so it’s quite possible you’ll only get around 8 
L353: hours despite their claims. Still, 8 hours of battery life on a laptop should be
L354:  enough to last a workday or a school day, all while letting you live 
L355: comfortably untethered. 
L356: 
L357: If in doubt about a particular laptop, check if PCWorld has reviewed it—【107†we 
L358: run battery tests】 to confirm if laptops live up to their promises.

L330: 
L331: Either way, opt for Intel or AMD if you care about performance. Just don’t 
L332: expect any high-end gaming! You’d need a dedicated GPU for that, and that’s not 
L333: happening in a budget laptop.
L334: 
L335: ## Battery life
L336: 
L337: [Image 5: laptop battery level indicator]
L338: 
L339: Panos Sakalakis / Unsplash 
L340: 
L341: You have lots of options when it comes to battery life, even in the affordable 
L342: laptop territory. Not only do weaker processors give you longer staying power, 
L343: but larger batteries can help too—if you’re willing to sacrifice weight and 
L344: portability.
L345: 
L346: And here, too, is an area where your choice of OS matters. Generally speaking, 
L347: Chromebooks usually last longer on a single charge than an equivalent Windows 
L348: laptop.
L349: 
L350: If you travel frequently or simply prefer to use your laptop unplugged, then aim
L351:  for one that promises 10 to 12 hours of battery life. Most manufacturers 
L352: overpromise and under deliver, so it’s quite possible you’ll only get around 8 
L353: hours despite their claims. Still, 8 hours of battery life on a laptop should be
L354:  enough to last a workday or a school day, all while letting you live 
L355: comfortably untethered. 
L356: 
L357: If in doubt about a particular laptop, check if PCWorld has reviewed it—【107†we 
L358: run battery tests】 to confirm if laptops live up to their promises.
L359: 
L360: ## Storage capacity
L361: 
L362: [Image 6: Internal SSDs]
L363: 
L364: Jon L. Jacobi 
L365: 
L366: Sticking to a budget means cutting some corners, and storage space is usually 
L367: among the first areas hit by compromise. That can be a problem if you aren’t 
L368: careful, though.
L369: 
L370: For the best laptop experience, you’ll want ample storage and you’ll want it to 
L371: be fast. A slow hard drive with inadequate capacity will leave you micromanaging
L372:  your files and apps as well as waiting inordinately long for files and apps to 
L373: load.
L374: 
L375: Among good budget options, you’ll find storage options ranging from 64GB to 
L376: 256GB. Obviously, more is better, but if you’re on Windows, you shouldn’t dip 
L377: below 128GB at the very least. (The operating system alone will take up around 
L378: 30GB, and modern apps are space hogs on top.) Anything less than 128GB and 
L379: you’ll find yourself running out of space so often that you’ll be tearing out 
L380: your hair.
L381: 
L382: Chromebooks, on the other hand, can survive pretty well on 64GB of storage for 
L383: several reasons: the OS doesn’t take up as much space, Chromebook apps are 
L384: typically smaller, and ChromeOS relies more on cloud storage than local storage.
L385:  The downside is that you basically need 24/7 internet access for day-to-day 
L386: use.
L387: 
L388: > Note: If you have to settle for a laptop with inadequate storage space, you 
L389: can always add an external drive to expand capacity. Just make sure the laptop 
L390: you get has enough ports for it (addressed later in this article), and stick to 
L391: 【108†our picks for best external drives】.
L392: 
L393: ## Storage types
L394: 
L395: [Image 7: Verschiedene Arten von SSD-Festplattenlaufwerken einzeln auf Laptop-
L396: Tastatur]
L397: 
L398: Maxx-Studio / Shutterstock.com 
L399: 
L400: Modern Windows laptops come with two primary options: SSD or eMMC. Don’t settle 
L401: for anything less than an SSD. Some cheaper laptops may offer eMMC drives, but 
L402: eMMC drives run very slow and fill up faster due to their smaller capacities. 
L403: You’ll be frustrated, trust me.
L404: 
L405: Chromebooks, however, tend to come with three options: SSD, eMMC, and UFS. 
L406: Again, I don’t recommend eMMC drives for the same reasons, but UFS is worth 
L407: considering. Universal Flash Storage is “newer” and more typically found on 
L408: mobile devices, but since ChromeOS is a mobile-like operating system, it’s well-
L409: suited to run on UFS.
L410: 
L411: In general, UFS is faster than eMMC but slower than an SSD. If you want the best
L412:  speeds, an SSD is still the best (but most expensive) option. If your goal is 
L413: to save money, you’ll do fine with a UFS drive.
L414: 
L415: ## Display resolution
L416: 
L417: [Image 8: Windows 11 mit dem neuen Bing Copilot direkt in das OS integriert.]
L418: 
L419: guteksk7 / Shutterstock.com 
L420: 
L421: At cheaper tiers, laptops mainly come with 720p or 1080p resolutions. I only saw
L422:  one laptop featuring a higher resolution, but that came at the expense of 
L423: cutting other corners.
L424: 
L425: So, when buying a budget laptop, you’ll want to stick to 1080p unless you’re 
L426: particularly strapped for cash. Going with 720p can save money, but the 
L427: experience is subpar: text is harder to read, video content suffers, and you 
L428: have less screen real estate for apps and files.
L429: 
L430: Stepping up to 1080p solves all of that, and you’ll appreciate the improved 
L431: resolution if you end up using your laptop to watch Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, etc.
L432: 
L433: ## Laptop size
L434: 
L435: [Image 9: Razer gaming laptop closed with logo on lid hero]
L436: 
L437: Thiago Trevisan / IDG 
L438: 
L439: The ideal laptop size really depends on your needs.
L440: 
L441: On the larger end, you have 15-inch and 17-inch laptops that provide bigger 
L442: screens and wider keyboards, but laptops at this size tend to be heavy and 
L443: detract from portability. And be aware that larger laptop screens may sometimes 
L444: have lower resolutions, which can affect crispness of image and the actual 
L445: amount of usable screen real estate. On the flip side, you have smaller 13-inch 
L446: laptops that are lighter and more portable but generally more cramped with 
L447: tighter keyboards.
L448: 
L449: I find that the sweet spot for portable productivity is with a 13-inch laptop 
L450: that has a 1080p resolution. You get ample screen real estate and crisp images, 
L451: a lightweight body that doesn’t take up much space in a bag, and the price is 
L452: usually quite affordable.
L453: 
L454: ## Ports and connectivity
L455: 
L456: [Image 10: External hard drive plugged into side of Windows laptop] 【109†Immo 
L457: Wegmann / Unsplash†go.skimresources.com】
L458: 
L459: Ports are important on budget laptops, especially if you’re sacrificing storage 
L460: space and screen size. With the right ports, you have the flexibility to connect
L461:  external drives and external monitors.
L462: 
L463: Thankfully, unless you go very low on price, you have good options. If possible,
L464:  aim for at least one USB-C port and one USB-A port. USB-C has taken over as the
L465:  dominant connector, but plenty of storage devices and other accessories still 
L466: rely on USB-A.
L467: 
L468: If you can find a budget laptop with an HDMI port as well, you should consider 
L469: it because it’ll make it easy to connect an external monitor. USB-C can 
L470: theoretically handle monitors as well, but not every USB-C port is built the 
L471: same and capable of supporting the same devices.
L472: 
L473: > Note: If you have to settle for a laptop with inadequate ports, you can always
L474:  add extra ports separately with a USB-C hub or docking station. See our picks 
L475: for 【110†best USB-C hubs】 and 【111†best Thunderbolt docks】.
L476: 
L477: ## Min specs for budget laptops in a nutshell 
L478: 
L479: Phew, that’s a lot to digest, so here’s a quick summary of my recommended 
L480: minimum specs for budget laptops without all the contextual explanations and

L477: ## Min specs for budget laptops in a nutshell 
L478: 
L479: Phew, that’s a lot to digest, so here’s a quick summary of my recommended 
L480: minimum specs for budget laptops without all the contextual explanations and 
L481: rationale:
L482: 
L483:   * RAM: 8GB minimum, 16GB if you can afford it.
L484:   * CPU: Intel i3 or AMD Ryzen 3 minimum, Intel i5 or AMD Ryzen 5 if you can 
L485: afford it.
L486:   * Battery life: At least 10 to 12 hours of claimed battery life (which is 
L487: likely closer to 8 hours in real-world usage).
L488:   * Storage capacity: 128GB minimum for Windows, 64GB minimum for Chromebooks. 
L489: If you need more space, you can always expand with an 【108†external storage 
L490: drive】.
L491:   * Storage types: SSD is what you want. For Chromebooks, you can get away with 
L492: UFS. Avoid eMMC at all cost.
L493:   * Display resolution: 1080p minimum.
L494:   * Laptop size: 13-inch for portability, 15-inch for screen space (as long as 
L495: you don’t sacrifice resolution to get there).
L496:   * Ports: At least one USB-C and one USB-A port, plus an HDMI port if you plan 
L497: to use an external monitor. Alternatively, buy a separate 【110†USB-C hub】 or 
L498: 【111†docking station】 to expand connectivity.
L499: 
L500: All of this can be had for under $500 if you shop around, especially if you can 
L501: be patient and wait for deals. I’ve seen laptops—both conventional and 2-in-1 
L502: laptops—that meet all these minimum specs, so you definitely don’t have to spend
L503:  a lot for a decent laptop.
L504: 
L505: As long as you aren’t expecting a powerhouse gaming machine that can rip videos 
L506: in no time flat, you’ll be fine. For more tips, check out 【112†our guide to 
L507: buying a budget laptop without getting screwed】, or head over to our guide on 
L508: 【104†the best laptops under $500】 if you want explicit recommendations.

L314: When it comes to CPUs on budget laptops, you have to temper your expectations. 
L315: You won’t be able to get anything truly powerful, but you will be able to find 
L316: something that suits your needs and gets you through non-intensive tasks like 
L317: office work, studying, and watching videos.
L318: 
L319: Among the more affordable Windows laptops, Intel i3 and i5 processors are the 
L320: most common options. Ideally you should opt for the i5, but you can settle for 
L321: an i3 if you’re on a tight budget; it should keep up with regular tasks as long 
L322: as you pair it with at least 8GB of RAM. AMD Ryzen 3 and Ryzen 5 processors are 
L323: also frequently seen in budget-tier laptops, and they can save you a little more
L324:  money than their Intel alternatives.
L325: 
L326: In Chromebooks, you’ll mostly find Intel i3 and i5 processors along with 
L327: MediaTek options. MediaTek processors are typically found in budget phones 
L328: because they have better battery life, but they have the disadvantage of being 
L329: less powerful.
L330: 
L331: Either way, opt for Intel or AMD if you care about performance. Just don’t 
L332: expect any high-end gaming! You’d need a dedicated GPU for that, and that’s not 
L333: happening in a budget laptop.
L334: 
L335: ## Battery life
L336: 
L337: [Image 5: laptop battery level indicator]
L338: 
L339: Panos Sakalakis / Unsplash 
L340: 
L341: You have lots of options when it comes to battery life, even in the affordable 
L342: laptop territory. Not only do weaker processors give you longer staying power, 
L343: but larger batteries can help too—if you’re willing to sacrifice weight and 
L344: portability.
L345: 
L346: And here, too, is an area where your choice of OS matters. Generally speaking, 
L347: Chromebooks usually last longer on a single charge than an equivalent Windows 
L348: laptop.
L349: 
L350: If you travel frequently or simply prefer to use your laptop unplugged, then aim
L351:  for one that promises 10 to 12 hours of battery life. Most manufacturers 
L352: overpromise and under deliver, so it’s quite possible you’ll only get around 8 
L353: hours despite their claims. Still, 8 hours of battery life on a laptop should be
L354:  enough to last a workday or a school day, all while letting you live 
L355: comfortably untethered. 
L356: 
L357: If in doubt about a particular laptop, check if PCWorld has reviewed it—【107†we 
L358: run battery tests】 to confirm if laptops live up to their promises.
L359: 
L360: ## Storage capacity
L361: 
L362: [Image 6: Internal SSDs]
L363: 
L364: Jon L. Jacobi 
L365: 
L366: Sticking to a budget means cutting some corners, and storage space is usually 
L367: among the first areas hit by compromise. That can be a problem if you aren’t 
L368: careful, though.
L369: 
L370: For the best laptop experience, you’ll want ample storage and you’ll want it to 
L371: be fast. A slow hard drive with inadequate capacity will leave you micromanaging
L372:  your files and apps as well as waiting inordinately long for files and apps to 
L373: load.
L374: 
L375: Among good budget options, you’ll find storage options ranging from 64GB to 
L376: 256GB. Obviously, more is better, but if you’re on Windows, you shouldn’t dip 
L377: below 128GB at the very least. (The operating system alone will take up around 
L378: 30GB, and modern apps are space hogs on top.) Anything less than 128GB and 
L379: you’ll find yourself running out of space so often that you’ll be tearing out 
L380: your hair.
L381: 
L382: Chromebooks, on the other hand, can survive pretty well on 64GB of storage for 
L383: several reasons: the OS doesn’t take up as much space, Chromebook apps are 
L384: typically smaller, and ChromeOS relies more on cloud storage than local storage.
L385:  The downside is that you basically need 24/7 internet access for day-to-day 
L386: use.
L387: 
L388: > Note: If you have to settle for a laptop with inadequate storage space, you 
L389: can always add an external drive to expand capacity. Just make sure the laptop 
L390: you get has enough ports for it (addressed later in this article), and stick to 
L391: 【108†our picks for best external drives】.
L392: 
L393: ## Storage types
L394: 
L395: [Image 7: Verschiedene Arten von SSD-Festplattenlaufwerken einzeln auf Laptop-
L396: Tastatur]
L397: 
L398: Maxx-Studio / Shutterstock.com 
L399: 
L400: Modern Windows laptops come with two primary options: SSD or eMMC. Don’t settle 
L401: for anything less than an SSD. Some cheaper laptops may offer eMMC drives, but 
L402: eMMC drives run very slow and fill up faster due to their smaller capacities. 
L403: You’ll be frustrated, trust me.
L404: 
L405: Chromebooks, however, tend to come with three options: SSD, eMMC, and UFS. 
L406: Again, I don’t recommend eMMC drives for the same reasons, but UFS is worth 
L407: considering. Universal Flash Storage is “newer” and more typically found on 
L408: mobile devices, but since ChromeOS is a mobile-like operating system, it’s well-
L409: suited to run on UFS.
L410: 
L411: In general, UFS is faster than eMMC but slower than an SSD. If you want the best
L412:  speeds, an SSD is still the best (but most expensive) option. If your goal is 
L413: to save money, you’ll do fine with a UFS drive.
L414: 
L415: ## Display resolution
L416: 
L417: [Image 8: Windows 11 mit dem neuen Bing Copilot direkt in das OS integriert.]
L418: 
L419: guteksk7 / Shutterstock.com 
L420: 
L421: At cheaper tiers, laptops mainly come with 720p or 1080p resolutions. I only saw
L422:  one laptop featuring a higher resolution, but that came at the expense of 
L423: cutting other corners.
L424: 
L425: So, when buying a budget laptop, you’ll want to stick to 1080p unless you’re 
L426: particularly strapped for cash. Going with 720p can save money, but the 
L427: experience is subpar: text is harder to read, video content suffers, and you 
L428: have less screen real estate for apps and files.
L429: 
L430: Stepping up to 1080p solves all of that, and you’ll appreciate the improved 
L431: resolution if you end up using your laptop to watch Netflix, Hulu, YouTube, etc.
L432: 
L433: ## Laptop size
L434: 
L435: [Image 9: Razer gaming laptop closed with logo on lid hero]
L436: 
L437: Thiago Trevisan / IDG 
L438: 
L439: The ideal laptop size really depends on your needs.
L440: 
L441: On the larger end, you have 15-inch and 17-inch laptops that provide bigger 
L442: screens and wider keyboards, but laptops at this size tend to be heavy and 
L443: detract from portability. And be aware that larger laptop screens may sometimes 
L444: have lower resolutions, which can affect crispness of image and the actual 
L445: amount of usable screen real estate. On the flip side, you have smaller 13-inch 
L446: laptops that are lighter and more portable but generally more cramped with 
L447: tighter keyboards.
L448: 
L449: I find that the sweet spot for portable productivity is with a 13-inch laptop 
L450: that has a 1080p resolution. You get ample screen real estate and crisp images, 
L451: a lightweight body that doesn’t take up much space in a bag, and the price is 
L452: usually quite affordable.
L453: 
L454: ## Ports and connectivity
L455: 
L456: [Image 10: External hard drive plugged into side of Windows laptop] 【109†Immo 
L457: Wegmann / Unsplash†go.skimresources.com】
L458: 
L459: Ports are important on budget laptops, especially if you’re sacrificing storage 
L460: space and screen size. With the right ports, you have the flexibility to connect
L461:  external drives and external monitors.
L462: 
L463: Thankfully, unless you go very low on price, you have good options. If possible,
L464:  aim for at least one USB-C port and one USB-A port. USB-C has taken over as the

High‑powered “cheap” laptops from China are a mixed bag.  On one end you have mainstream Chinese manufacturers like **Lenovo**, **Huawei**, **Xiaomi** and **ASUS** that have become global powerhouses.  Canalys data shows that in Q4 2024 Lenovo shipped roughly **16.9 million** laptops worldwide and has maintained the #1 market share【974435448442152†L119-L133】; its ThinkPad, Legion and Yoga lines are known for solid build quality and innovative designs (foldable screens, e‑ink lids)【426002845858368†L555-L563】.  Xiaomi’s Mi Notebook Pro and RedmiBook series pack mid‑range Intel Core processors, SSD storage and thin metal chassis at student‑friendly prices【974435448442152†L169-L176】.  These laptops compete directly with Dell and Apple in performance and design while often costing less【974435448442152†L73-L76】.

On the other end are **budget brands** like **Chuwi** and **Teclast**, which target price‑sensitive markets.  They deliver decent specs for casual use – Chuwi’s CoreBook X comes with a 12th‑gen Intel Core i5, 16 GB RAM and a 2K screen【864461160134218†L229-L241】 – but the low price hides compromises.  TechRadar notes that the CoreBook X “lacks an easy means to upgrade the storage,” offers only USB 3.0‑grade ports and omits biometric security【864461160134218†L244-L248】.  Reviewers also point out that its battery struggles to last a full workday【864461160134218†L252-L257】.  Many budget sellers on marketplaces misrepresent their hardware: PCWorld found that a top‑selling “Lenovo IdeaPad” on Amazon claimed huge RAM and storage but used a sluggish Celeron N4500 processor that scores **~731** on Geekbench – far slower than a modern Core Ultra 120U (~7,500 points)【92524522479053†L251-L263】.  Some listings also hype integrated graphics as “gaming‑class” when they’re two generations old【92524522479053†L280-L306】.

### Are they worth it?

- **Reputable Chinese brands (Lenovo, ASUS, Huawei, Xiaomi)** – Yes, these can be great values.  They offer current‑generation CPUs, good displays and respectable build quality at prices lower than many U.S. brands.  Warranty and support are usually solid in North America for Lenovo and ASUS, while Huawei laptops are harder to buy in the U.S. but popular abroad【974435448442152†L145-L159】.  If you choose one of these brands, you’re essentially buying a mainstream laptop that happens to be made in China.
- **No‑name budget brands (Chuwi, Teclast and Amazon‑only sellers)** – Approach with caution.  They can be worth it if your needs are basic (web, Office, streaming) and you accept trade‑offs like shorter battery life, older processors and limited support.  Avoid listings that look “too good to be true,” and don’t trust enormous discount percentages.  Always verify the CPU/GPU model and search for its release year; PCWorld advises avoiding CPUs older than **two years** and GPUs older than **three years**【92524522479053†L344-L359】.  Check seller reviews – some buyers reported receiving used or completely different machines【92524522479053†L265-L268】.

### What to look for (processing speed and other specs)

| Spec/Feature | Recommended minimum for a decent experience (budget/low‑cost laptops) | Why it matters |
|---|---|---|
| **CPU** | At least an **Intel Core i3/i5** or **AMD Ryzen 3/5** (12th gen or newer).  PCWorld notes that i3/i5 or Ryzen 3/5 chips handle everyday tasks and cost‑effectively【50831543413637†L314-L323】.  Avoid older Celeron/Pentium chips or random “10‑core” marketing claims – they often deliver poor real‑world performance【92524522479053†L251-L263】. | Modern CPUs have better single‑thread speed and efficiency, essential for responsive multitasking. |
| **RAM (memory)** | **8 GB minimum**, **16 GB** if you can swing it【50831543413637†L297-L304】. | Insufficient RAM is the main reason cheap laptops feel slow when multiple tabs or apps are open. |
| **Storage** | **128 GB SSD** minimum for Windows, **64 GB** for ChromeOS【50831543413637†L375-L379】.  Use SSDs or UFS; avoid slow eMMC drives【50831543413637†L400-L405】. | SSDs dramatically reduce boot and load times compared with eMMC or HDD. |
| **Battery** | Claims of **10–12 hours** usually translate to ~8 hours in real use【50831543413637†L350-L355】.  Look for at least this rating unless you’re comfortable carrying a charger. | A strong battery prevents mid‑day charging panic. |
| **Display** | **1080p (Full HD)** resolution is the minimum for comfortable reading and video【50831543413637†L421-L431】.  Some cheap laptops advertise 2K panels (like Chuwi’s 2160×1440)【864461160134218†L229-L241】, but watch for sacrifices in other areas. | Higher resolution improves clarity; 720p displays look grainy and cramped. |
| **Ports** | At least **one USB‑C and one USB‑A**, plus HDMI for external monitors【50831543413637†L459-L468】.  Budget Chinese laptops sometimes skimp on modern ports【864461160134218†L244-L248】. | Adequate ports ensure you can connect drives, peripherals and displays without dongle overload. |
| **GPU** (for gaming/graphics) | Integrated graphics (Intel UHD/Iris or AMD Radeon iGPU) are fine for light tasks.  If you plan to game or edit video, look for an NVIDIA RTX 4060 or better; Lenovo’s Legion 5i with an RTX 4060 offers strong gaming value【92524522479053†L399-L403】. | “Gaming laptops” with only integrated Vega or UHD graphics often can’t handle modern games smoothly【92524522479053†L294-L303】. |

### Bottom line

If you stick with established Chinese brands and ensure the CPU, RAM and storage meet modern baseline specs, a “cheap” Chinese laptop can deliver tremendous bang for your buck.  For general productivity, a recent Core i5/Ryzen 5 with 16 GB of RAM and a 512 GB SSD will feel plenty snappy.  For gaming or creative work, expect to pay more for a model with a discrete GPU and better cooling.  Most importantly, resist the siren song of ultra‑cheap listings that promise “high performance” with unspecified processors or unrealistic discounts.  Do your research, verify hardware release dates, and buy from reputable sellers.

With those caveats in mind, a wallet‑friendly laptop from the Middle Kingdom can absolutely be a smart purchase – just make sure you’re not trading away the fundamentals for a flashy spec sheet.
